context:
<Summary source="https://www.morningstar.com/stocks/rivian-shares-fall-deliveries-decline">
# Summary of Morningstar Article on Rivian Deliveries (January 5, 2026)

## Key Facts and Statistics:
- **Q4 2025 deliveries:** 9,745 vehicles
- **Full year 2025 deliveries:** 42,284 vehicles
- Q4 2025 deliveries were down 31% (year-over-year)
- Full year 2025 deliveries were down 18% (year-over-year)
- Shares fell approximately 3% on January 2, 2026
- The 2025 deliveries were slightly above Morningstar's estimate but just below the midpoint of guidance and consensus estimate

## Morningstar's Opinions and Forecasts:
- **Fair Value Estimate:** $15.00 per share
- **Morningstar Rating:** 2-star (overvalued)
- **Economic Moat Rating:** None
- **Uncertainty Rating:** Very High
- Current stock price trades approximately 25% above their fair value estimate

### 2026 Outlook from Morningstar:
- **Overall 2026 deliveries:** Expected to rise (despite broader US EV market weakness) due to R2 launch
- **First half 2026:** Expects lower volumes as R2 production ramps up
- **Second half 2026:** Expects growth
- **US EV market:** Expected to continue falling through the first three quarters of 2026

## Context:
- Rivian was affected by the expiration of the US EV tax credit in September 2025
- The company sells most of its vehicles in the United States
- New R2 midsize SUV starting price: $45,000 (significantly lower than R1 truck and full-size SUV)
- R2 production planned to begin in 2026
- Morningstar expects negative free cash flow for at least the next four years

**Author:** Seth Goldstein, CFA (Morningstar Equity Research)
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://intellectia.ai/blog/rivian-rivn-stock-forecast-2026-r2-launch">
# Summary of Rivian RIVN - 2026 Stock Forecast & R2 Launch Article

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**Recent Financial Performance:**
- Q3 2025 revenue: $1.56 billion (78% year-over-year increase)
- Q3 2025 vehicle sales: $1.14 billion (47% YoY increase)
- Q3 2025 software/services revenue: $416 million (324% YoY increase)
- Q3 2025 gross profit: $24 million (third consecutive quarter of positive gross profit)
- Q3 2025 vehicle deliveries: approximately 18,000 vehicles

**2025 Full Year:**
- Expected revenue: $4.7-$4.9 billion (down from $4.97 billion in 2024)
- Q4 2025 deliveries: 9,745 vehicles (31% decrease YoY)
- Full year 2025 deliveries: 42,247 vehicles (18% decrease from 2024)

**2026 Projections:**
- Market experts predict approximately 66,000 EV deliveries in 2026
- Expected 2026 sales: $6.9 billion
- R2 launch scheduled for early 2026 with $45,000 starting price
- Annual production capacity: up to 155,000 vehicles starting in 2026

**Balance Sheet:**
- Cash position: $7-$7.2 billion as of Q3 2025 (provides approximately 3 years of operational funding)

**Manufacturing Capacity:**
- Normal, Illinois plant capacity: 150,000 vehicles yearly (not at full capacity yet)

**Long-term Projections:**
- Break-even not expected until 2027
- Revenue growth projected from $4.8 billion (2025) to $9.6-$14.5 billion by 2030
- Target margins: high teens adjusted EBITDA margin and 10% free cash flow margin

## Analyst Opinions:

**Wall Street Consensus:**
- Overall rating: "Hold"
- One-year price target: $17.68 (suggesting potential downside)
- 24/7 Wall St. prediction: $14.57 by end of 2026 (25.4% potential drop)
- Some analysts project 54.49% rise over next 3 months
- Some analysts suggest stock could reach $39.27 per share (trading at 7x sales)

**Named Source:**
- Wedbush Securities analysts call 2026 "a turning point for Rivian"

## Other Relevant Information:

- U.S. EV market sales dropped more than 41% in November 2025
- Rivian stock climbed 46% in 2025 after extended post-IPO decline
- Stock has dropped more than 80% from its peak
- Amazon partnership: 100,000 electric delivery van order by 2030
- Company owns more than 1,000 patents for EV technologies

**Note:** The article appears to be promotional/investment analysis content from Intellectia.ai and contains mixed timeframes and potentially conflicting projections from various unnamed sources.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://tridenstechnology.com/rivian-sales-statistics/">
# Summary of Rivian 2025 Sales, Revenue & Production Statistics Article

**Source:** Tridens, January 15, 2026, by Thiong'o Waweru

## Key Facts and Statistics Relevant to Q1 2026 Deliveries:

### 2025 Performance Data:
- **Global Deliveries 2025:** 42,247 vehicles (down 18% from 51,579 in 2024)
- **Production 2025:** 42,284 vehicles (down 14.5% from 49,476 in 2024)

### Historical Delivery Trends:
| Year | Deliveries | Growth (%) |
|------|-----------|------------|
| 2021 | 920 | N/A |
| 2022 | 20,332 | +2,109% |
| 2023 | 50,122 | +147% |
| 2024 | 51,579 | +3% |
| 2025 | 42,247 | -18% |

### Manufacturing Capacity and Facilities:
- **Normal, IL factory:** 150,000 vehicles annual capacity (currently produces R1T, R1S, EDV)
- **Georgia plant:** Expected to open in 2026 with 400,000-vehicle capacity (will produce R2 and R3 models)
  - Note: Construction starts in 2026, production planned for 2028

### Context for 2025 Decline:
The article states that 2025's production drop to 42,284 was "due to a factory shutdown for retooling for the R2 and R3 models." Similarly, quarterly performance in 2025 showed "the drop after is due to factory shutdown in preparing for the R 2 and R 3 models."

### Other Relevant Information:
- **Workforce 2025:** ~14,700 employees (down from ~16,500 in 2024)
- **Revenue 2025:** ~$5.0 billion (approximately the same as 2024)
- **Amazon EDV Deliveries:** 20,000 units by 2025 (part of 100,000-unit order by 2030)

**Note:** The article text appears to be cut off mid-sentence and does not contain specific Q1 2025 quarterly delivery data that would provide direct comparison for forecasting Q1 2026.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://electrek.co/2026/01/05/lucid-lcid-beats-odds-q4-production-surges-100/">
# Summary of Article: Lucid (LCID) beats the odds after Q4 production surges more than 100%

**Source:** Electrek  
**Date:** January 05, 2026  
**Author:** Peter Johnson

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### Lucid Q4 2025 Performance:
- **Production:** 8,412 vehicles produced in Q4 2025
  - Up 116% from Q3 2025
  - Up 148% from Q4 2024
- **Deliveries:** 5,345 vehicles delivered in Q4 2025
  - Up 73% year-over-year

### Lucid Full Year 2025 Performance:
- **Production:** 18,378 vehicles total
  - Up 103% (doubled) from 2024
  - Had produced only 9,966 vehicles through first nine months of 2025
  - Original full-year guidance was 18,000 to 20,000 vehicles
- **Deliveries:** 15,841 vehicles total
  - Up 55% from 2024

### Financial Information:
- Lucid had approximately $4.2 billion in liquidity at end of Q3 2025
- After agreement with Saudi PIF to increase delayed draw term loan credit facility (DDTL), total liquidity would be around $5.5 billion
- According to Lucid, this capital is sufficient to fund operations through first half of 2027

### Future Plans:
- Lucid will begin production of its midsize platform later in 2026
- Platform will include at least three variants, including a midsize electric SUV starting at around $50,000
- Q4 2025 financial results scheduled for release on Tuesday, February 24, 2026

## Context:
The article notes that Lucid's strong performance contrasts with Tesla and Rivian, which both reported fewer deliveries in Q4 2025.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cbtnews.com/rivian-sees-32-increase-in-q3-deliveries-as-tax-credits-end/">
# Summary of Article: "Rivian sees 32% increase in Q3 deliveries as tax credits end"

**Key Facts and Statistics:**

- **Q3 2025 deliveries:** Rivian reported 13,201 vehicle deliveries, representing a nearly 32% increase over the previous period
- **Analyst expectations:** Q3 deliveries surpassed analysts' forecast of 12,690 vehicles
- **2025 delivery guidance:** Rivian narrowed its full-year 2025 guidance to 41,500–43,500 vehicles
- **Previous guidance:** The company had cut guidance in May 2025 from as many as 51,000 vehicles
- **Tax credit expiration:** U.S. federal EV tax credits expired on Tuesday (preceding the October 2, 2025 article date)

**Context and Challenges:**

- The Q3 delivery surge partially reflects a rush by U.S. buyers to secure tax credits before their expiration
- Tariffs on imported auto parts have increased production costs and compressed margins for EV makers
- Rising vehicle costs and supply chain pressures are impacting the company
- Rivian is preparing to launch its more affordable R2 SUV in 2026 (referred to as "next year" in the October 2025 article)

**Analyst/Industry Opinions:**

- Industry analysts predict the expiration of consumer tax credits could negatively impact EV sales and leasing in coming quarters
- Analysts note that while short-term delivery numbers may fluctuate, long-term growth depends on the company's ability to scale more accessible models and ongoing shifts in U.S. EV policy
- Despite uncertainties, Rivian's Q3 performance shows demand remains resilient when incentives are in place
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://riviantrackr.com/news/rivian-hits-2025-targets-despite-ev-policy-and-demand-pressure/">
# Summary of Article: "Rivian Hits 2025 Targets Despite EV Policy and Demand Pressure"

**Source:** RivianTrackr  
**Date:** January 02, 2026  
**Author:** Jose Castillo

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**2025 Full Year Results:**
- Production: 42,284 vehicles
- Deliveries: 42,247 vehicles
- Result: Finished inside company's revised guidance

**Q4 2025 Results:**
- Production: 10,974 vehicles
- Deliveries: 9,745 vehicles

**Historical Comparison:**
- 2023: ~57,000 vehicles produced, just over 50,000 delivered
- 2024: ~49,500 produced, ~51,500 delivered
- 2025: ~42,000 produced and delivered

## Policy Context:

- Federal EV tax credit (previously worth up to $7,500 for new EVs) expired on September 30, 2025
- Expiration occurred under tax law signed by President Trump earlier in 2025
- This change removed a key cost advantage for EV buyers and has been "widely cited as a headwind for EV demand and new EV sales"

## Other Relevant Information:

- Rivian will release full Q4 and full year 2025 financial results on February 12, 2026, after markets close
- Management earnings webcast scheduled for 5:00 p.m. ET on February 12, 2026
- The article characterizes 2025 as showing "tighter demand and more conservative production" as Rivian navigated "a tougher EV market and shifting incentives"
</Summary>

Query: Latest analyst estimates of Rivian first-quarter 2026 vehicle deliveries and any official company guidance since January 2026
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Where Will Rivian Stock Be in 5 Years?​**
Rivian (NASDAQ: RIVN) went public on November 10, 2021, at $78 per share, but its stock has since declined to $15 as of January 30, 2026, due to unmet production targets, high losses, and difficulty controlling costs. The company produces the R1T pickup, R1S SUV, and custom electric delivery vans (EDVs) for Amazon and others, with plans to launch the R2 SUV in early 2026. In 2022, Rivian produced only 24,337 vehicles (vs. a 50,000 target), delivering 20,332. Production rose to 57,232 in 2023 with 50,122 deliveries, but dipped to 49,476 in 2024, with deliveries reaching 51,579 despite inflation, high interest rates, reduced EV subsidies, and competition. For 2025, Rivian expects deliveries of 40,000 to 46,000 vehicles. Over the next five years, analysts project Rivian’s revenue will grow at a 31% CAGR from 2024 to 2027, with net losses narrowing. The company aims to boost gross margins through clean energy credit sales, subscription services, upgrades, and licensing. A joint venture with Volkswagen (OTC: VWAP.Y) is advancing new EV architecture and software. Rivian plans to open its Georgia plant and triple production capacity by 2028. If Rivian achieves a 20% revenue CAGR through 2031 and trades at 5x sales by 2031—up from under 3x sales in 2024—its stock could rise more than sixfold. However, this growth depends on successful scaling, market expansion, and overcoming macro and microeconomic headwinds. The Motley Fool notes Rivian’s stock is currently undervalued, trading at less than three times 2024 sales.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 30, 2026 06:35 PM
Source:[The Motley Fool](https://www.fool.com/investing/2026/01/30/where-will-rivian-stock-be-in-5-years/?source=newstex&utm_source=newstex&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=article&referring_guid=6667fdc5-1538-43b3-9d48-2e406b810d1a)

**CNET Cars: Navigate Your World in This New Age of Transportation**
CNET Cars presents a comprehensive overview of the evolving transportation landscape, highlighting key developments in electric vehicles, autonomous technology, and personal mobility. The article previews the upcoming Rivian R2 electric SUV, predicted to become the brand's most popular model by 2026 due to its 300+ mile range and affordable starting price. It covers major industry updates, including Waymo expanding its robotaxi service to San Francisco and launching an investigation after a robotaxi struck a young pedestrian near a school in January 2026. Audi, Porsche, and Volkswagen issued a major recall due to a rearview camera glitch. Tesla is transitioning its 'Full Self-Driving' software to a subscription-only model. The site also features expert reviews of electric scooters, e-bikes, and campervans, along with recommendations for the best electric cars of 2024 and top engine oils. The article was published on January 30, 2026, by CNET.
Original language: unknown
Publish date: January 30, 2026 02:17 PM
Source:[cnet.com](https://www.cnet.com/roadshow/)

**Rivian R2 on the Final Straight: The Game-Changing Electric Crossover Now on the Production Line**
Rivian's R2, a midsize electric crossover, is nearing production readiness and is expected to reach customers as early as June 2026, according to Carscoops. The vehicle is being produced at a newly expanded 2.6 million square foot manufacturing facility in Normal, Illinois, which was completed in just 11 months. The first validation vehicles—actual production prototypes, not early models—have already rolled off the assembly line, confirming the readiness of key manufacturing processes. The plant has a peak capacity of 215,000 vehicles annually, with 155,000 units allocated to the R2 model. Initially, Rivian planned to produce the R2 in Georgia, but due to delays in that project, the company shifted production to Illinois for speed. The R2 is built on a completely new midsize platform, and while final specifications remain unannounced, Rivian aims to maintain a starting price of approximately $45,000. This pricing is critical for direct competition with the Tesla Model Y; if achieved, the R2 could transition from a brand image vehicle to a serious market contender. The success of the R2 launch could determine whether Rivian becomes a major player in the U.S. mass-market electric vehicle sector or remains a niche producer of premium vehicles.
Original language: uk
Publish date: January 29, 2026 05:50 PM
Source:[newsyou.info](https://newsyou.info/2026/01/rivian-r2-na-finishnij-pryamij-dolenosnij-elektrokrosover-vzhe-na-konveyeri)

**Rivian Electric Vehicles: Reviews, Pricing, and Specs**
Rivian, a California-based electric vehicle manufacturer, offers a range of vehicles including the R1T pickup truck, the R1S full-size SUV, the mid-size R2 SUV, and upcoming entry-level models R3 and R3X. The R1T has received a perfect 10/10 rating from Car and Driver, with starting prices from $69,300 (2022) to $74,885 (2026) and an EPA-estimated range of 67–87 combined miles. The R1S SUV has consistently earned an 8.5/10 rating, with starting prices ranging from $76,700 (2024) to $79,800 (2023), and an EPA-estimated range of 258–410 miles. The R2 SUV is projected to start at $45,000 (estimated) for the 2026 model year, while the R3 and R3X are expected to launch in 2027 as more affordable, compact options. Rivian also produces an electric commercial van used by Amazon, with a starting price of $79,900 (2026 model). All vehicles emphasize off-road capability and advanced technology. Car and Driver has awarded the R1T and R1S the '10Best' and 'EV of the Year' accolades, and both models are recognized as 'Editors' Choice' and 'C/D Rating' winners.
Original language: unknown
Publish date: January 29, 2026 01:26 PM
Source:[caranddriver.com](https://caranddriver.com/rivian/)

**Rivian (RIVN) Stock: Dips Ahead of Feb. 12 Earnings Amid Weak EV Demand**
Rivian (NASDAQ: RIVN) shares declined to $15.20 on January 29, 2026, a 0.5% drop for the day but a nearly 30% decline since late December 2025, when they closed at $21.75. The stock dip reflects investor concerns over weak demand for Rivian’s high-end electric trucks and SUVs, as well as uncertainty ahead of the company’s Q4 and full-year 2025 earnings report on February 12. Despite producing 10,974 vehicles and delivering 9,745 in Q4, Rivian’s total 2025 deliveries reached 42,247 units—below some analyst expectations. The company’s planned expansion into the smaller R2 model, scheduled for release in the first half of 2026, may pressure margins if delayed. Rivian’s partnership with Volkswagen, particularly the software collaboration tied to a new EV platform and a potential $1 billion milestone payment, is under scrutiny, with winter testing ongoing in Sweden. Additionally, Rivian’s ambitious software and services strategy—including self-driving technology and AI-driven features—faces market skepticism, especially after gains from its December Autonomy and AI Day were reversed. The broader EV sector remains turbulent, with the expiration of the $7,500 U.S. EV tax credit in September 2025 and rising competition from Tesla and Lucid compounding challenges. Analysts emphasize Rivian’s need to balance software innovation with cash conservation amid a market reshaped by shifting consumer incentives and technological advancements.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2026 08:15 AM
Source:[Parameter](https://parameter.io/rivian-rivn-stock-dips-feb-12-earnings-ev-demand/)

**Tesla plots $20 billion spending spree to build Elon Musk's AI future**
Tesla Inc. announced a $20 billion capital expenditure plan for 2026—double what Wall Street expected—to pivot from an electric vehicle (EV) manufacturer toward artificial intelligence (AI), robotics, and autonomous driving. The investment will expand production across multiple factories, scale the nascent robotaxi business, and build AI infrastructure. Tesla also revealed plans to discontinue the high-end Model S and Model X vehicles, redirecting that production capacity toward building Optimus humanoid robots. CEO Elon Musk emphasized the company’s 'very, very big investments' during a post-earnings call. The company reached a $2 billion investment agreement with Musk’s xAI startup, including a framework to enhance AI development and deployment in the physical world. This move reinforces the deep integration between Tesla and Musk’s other ventures, despite a prior shareholder vote that failed to pass a nonbinding measure supporting such an investment. Tesla reported adjusted earnings per share of 50 cents, beating analyst estimates by 5 cents, marking the first profit beat in four quarters. However, vehicle deliveries declined 9% year-over-year in 2025, with a 16% drop in the fourth quarter, driven by lower EV demand, increased competition, and the loss of regulatory credit revenue, which fell 22% in Q4. Regulatory credits, once a lucrative income stream, have dried up following the Trump administration’s elimination of penalties for automakers failing to meet fuel economy standards. Despite the EV sales slump, Tesla’s Full Self-Driving (FSD) software now has 1.1 million active subscribers—up nearly 40% from a year earlier—and will become subscription-only after February 14. Tesla is expanding its robotaxi service to Dallas, Houston, Phoenix, Miami, Orlando, Tampa, and Las Vegas in the first half of 2026. The company launched automated rideshare operations in Austin in June 2025, began rolling out robotaxis without human supervisors in January 2026, and continues to operate non-autonomous rideshare services in the San Francisco Bay Area, with testing permits in Nevada and Arizona. The stock rose 1.2% in after-hours trading, reflecting investor optimism about Tesla’s AI and robotics future.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 29, 2026 02:56 AM
Source:[Economic Times](https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/tech/artificial-intelligence/tesla-plots-20-billion-spending-spree-to-build-elon-musks-ai-future/articleshow/127751060.cms)

**Tesla Discontinues Model S and Model X, Paving the Way for Optimus Robot Production**
Tesla has announced the discontinuation of the Model S and Model X, marking the end of its flagship vehicle lineup as part of a strategic shift toward automation and the production of Optimus humanoid robots. The decision follows years of declining sales, with Model S and Model X combined accounting for a small percentage of Tesla's annual deliveries—over 1.7 million units annually since 2022—leading Tesla to stop reporting their sales separately starting in 2023, grouping them with Cybertruck and Tesla Semi under 'other vehicles.' The Fremont factory, which previously produced these models with a design capacity of about 100,000 units annually, has been operating at low capacity. Elon Musk cited 'autonomy' as the primary reason for the shutdown, stating that production lines will be repurposed for Optimus robots, with a target annual output of 1 million units. Tesla will continue providing after-sales service but will stop deliveries after the second quarter of 2026, with no further production once current inventory is depleted. A minor update in July 2025—adding new colors, a front camera, slightly improved range, and ambient lighting—was widely seen as a token gesture, with prices increased by $5,000 (Model S to $84,990, Model X to $89,990), signaling a farewell tour. Historically, Model S (2012–2026) and Model X (2015–2026) were pivotal in establishing Tesla’s brand, serving as financial foundations for the more mass-market Model 3 and Model Y, and defining the premium electric vehicle segment. However, platform aging and competition from Lucid Air and Rivian R1S have eroded their market leadership. Industry analysts, including Electrek, note that the decision was 'inevitable' from a manufacturing standpoint due to the high complexity and low volume of these models. The move symbolizes the end of an era, as these vehicles once inspired early adopters and forced traditional automakers to embrace electrification. With the discontinuation of Model S and Model X, Tesla has officially closed the chapter on its flagship era, redirecting resources toward future automation goals.
Original language: zh
Publish date: January 29, 2026 12:00 AM
Source:[inside.com.tw](https://www.inside.com.tw/article/40584-tesla-ends-model-s-and-model-x-as-flagship-line-makes-way-for-optimus)

**Is Rivian Stock a Buy Now?**
Rivian Automotive (RIVN) is at a critical juncture in its development, with its long-term viability hinging on the success of its upcoming lower-priced truck, the R2, set for release in 2026. While Rivian has achieved notable milestones—producing award-winning vehicles, scaling production, and achieving gross profit in multiple quarters of 2024 and 2025—it remains unprofitable overall, with net losses persisting. The company posted a modest gross profit in Q4 2024, Q1 2025, and Q3 2025, but not in Q2 2025. Despite having $7 billion in cash as of Q3 2025, Rivian's future depends on its ability to transition from serving business customers and high-end consumers to capturing the mass market with the R2. The article cautions that while Rivian has made impressive progress, its capital-intensive nature and intense competition make mass-market success uncertain. The Motley Fool advises most investors to wait for evidence of the R2’s market reception before investing, noting that a weak launch could severely impact the company. The recommendation is to approach with caution and delay investment until post-launch performance data is available.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 28, 2026 11:45 PM
Source:[The Motley Fool](https://www.fool.com/investing/2026/01/28/is-rivian-stock-a-buy-now/)

**Tesla (TSLA) Stock Slips After Q4 Results – Time to Buy?**
Tesla's Q4 2025 earnings report revealed a 3% year-over-year decline in revenue and a 60% drop in earnings per share, leading to a 3.36% stock decline to $416.98 on January 30, 2026, despite an initial post-earnings rally. Automotive revenue fell 11% as total vehicle deliveries dropped 16%. CEO Elon Musk confirmed the discontinuation of Model S and Model X production starting in Q1 2026, marking a strategic pivot toward autonomy. Full self-driving (FSD) subscriptions reached 1.1 million users, a 38% year-over-year increase, outpacing vehicle delivery growth of 22%. Robotaxi operations currently serve Austin and the San Francisco Bay Area with around 500 vehicles, with plans to expand to seven new cities in H1 2026. Cybercab production is set to begin in April 2026, with Tesla aiming to double its robotaxi fleet monthly. The company plans to spend over $20 billion on capital expenditures in 2026—more than double the $8.5 billion spent in 2025. Free cash flow declined 30% year-over-year to $1.4 billion. Energy storage deployment reached 14.2 gigawatt-hours in Q4, up 29% year-over-year. Tesla will unveil the Optimus Gen 3 humanoid robot this quarter, with production expected before end-2026 and annual capacity targeting 1 million units. Analyst Jed Dorsheimer estimates Optimus could generate $25 billion in revenue at 500,000 units annually. Wedbush analyst Dan Ives remains bullish, projecting Tesla could reach a $2 trillion market cap by early 2026 and $3 trillion by year-end in a bull case scenario. Tesla did not provide 2026 vehicle delivery guidance, citing demand, supply chain readiness, and fleet allocation as key variables.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 30, 2026 12:15 PM
Source:[CoinCentral](https://coincentral.com/tesla-tsla-stock-slips-after-q4-results-time-to-buy/)

**Rivian Electric Vehicles: Reviews, Pricing, and Specs**
Rivian, a California-based electric vehicle manufacturer, offers a range of vehicles including the R1T pickup truck, the R1S full-size SUV, the mid-size R2 SUV, and upcoming entry-level models R3 and R3X. The R1T has received a perfect 10/10 rating from Car and Driver, with starting prices from $69,300 (2022) to $74,885 (2026) and an EPA-estimated range of 67–87 combined miles. The R1S SUV has consistently earned an 8.5/10 rating, with starting prices ranging from $76,700 (2024) to $79,800 (2023), and an EPA-estimated range of 258–410 miles. The R2 SUV is projected to start at $45,000 (estimated) for the 2026 model year, while the R3 and R3X are expected to launch in 2027 as more affordable, compact options. Rivian also produces an electric commercial van used by Amazon, with a starting price of $79,900 (2026 model). All vehicles emphasize off-road capability and advanced technology. Car and Driver has awarded the R1T and R1S the '10Best' and 'EV of the Year' accolades, and both models are recognized as 'Editors' Choice' and 'C/D Rating' winners.

**Rivian (RIVN) Stock: Dips Ahead of Feb. 12 Earnings Amid Weak EV Demand**
Rivian (NASDAQ: RIVN) shares declined to $15.20 on January 29, 2026, a 0.5% drop for the day but a nearly 30% decline since late December 2025, when they closed at $21.75. The stock dip reflects investor concerns over weak demand for Rivian’s high-end electric trucks and SUVs, as well as uncertainty ahead of the company’s Q4 and full-year 2025 earnings report on February 12. Despite producing 10,974 vehicles and delivering 9,745 in Q4, Rivian’s total 2025 deliveries reached 42,247 units—below some analyst expectations. The company’s planned expansion into the smaller R2 model, scheduled for release in the first half of 2026, may pressure margins if delayed. Rivian’s partnership with Volkswagen, particularly the software collaboration tied to a new EV platform and a potential $1 billion milestone payment, is under scrutiny, with winter testing ongoing in Sweden. Additionally, Rivian’s ambitious software and services strategy—including self-driving technology and AI-driven features—faces market skepticism, especially after gains from its December Autonomy and AI Day were reversed. The broader EV sector remains turbulent, with the expiration of the $7,500 U.S. EV tax credit in September 2025 and rising competition from Tesla and Lucid compounding challenges. Analysts emphasize Rivian’s need to balance software innovation with cash conservation amid a market reshaped by shifting consumer incentives and technological advancements.

**Tesla to Discontinue Model S and Model X Production by Q2 2026 to Accelerate Optimus Robot Rollout**
Tesla has announced that the production of its flagship vehicles, the Model S sedan and Model X SUV, will cease by the second quarter of 2026, according to CEO Elon Musk during the company’s Q4 2025 earnings call. The vehicles are currently produced at Tesla’s Fremont, California factory. Musk stated that the decision marks a transition toward a future centered on autonomous driving, and urged potential buyers to purchase Model S or Model X now. After the discontinuation, the same production space will be repurposed for the production of the humanoid robot project, Optimus, with a target annual capacity of 1 million units at the Fremont plant. Model S, launched in 2012, was widely regarded as the first mass-appeal luxury electric car, while Model X, introduced in 2015, was Tesla’s second major electric vehicle project. Despite upgrades, sales of both models have stagnated in recent years amid increasing competition from traditional automakers and new entrants like Rivian and Lucid. Tesla has been training Optimus prototypes at the Fremont factory for over a year. Musk confirmed in Davos that the robots have already performed simple tasks in the factory and are expected to handle more complex duties by the end of 2025, with public sales projected to begin by the end of 2026. Data collection for Optimus will also start at Tesla’s Austin, Texas factory in February 2026. Musk acknowledged the emotional weight of ending the Model S and Model X era, but emphasized that it is time to shift focus toward higher-volume vehicles and cutting-edge initiatives like autonomous driving and robotics, signaling a new phase of scalability and automation for Tesla.

**Tesla plots $20 billion spending spree to build Elon Musk's AI future**
Tesla Inc. announced a $20 billion capital expenditure plan for 2026—double what Wall Street expected—to pivot from an electric vehicle (EV) manufacturer toward artificial intelligence (AI), robotics, and autonomous driving. The investment will expand production across multiple factories, scale the nascent robotaxi business, and build AI infrastructure. Tesla also revealed plans to discontinue the high-end Model S and Model X vehicles, redirecting that production capacity toward building Optimus humanoid robots. CEO Elon Musk emphasized the company’s 'very, very big investments' during a post-earnings call. The company reached a $2 billion investment agreement with Musk’s xAI startup, including a framework to enhance AI development and deployment in the physical world. This move reinforces the deep integration between Tesla and Musk’s other ventures, despite a prior shareholder vote that failed to pass a nonbinding measure supporting such an investment. Tesla reported adjusted earnings per share of 50 cents, beating analyst estimates by 5 cents, marking the first profit beat in four quarters. However, vehicle deliveries declined 9% year-over-year in 2025, with a 16% drop in the fourth quarter, driven by lower EV demand, increased competition, and the loss of regulatory credit revenue, which fell 22% in Q4. Regulatory credits, once a lucrative income stream, have dried up following the Trump administration’s elimination of penalties for automakers failing to meet fuel economy standards. Despite the EV sales slump, Tesla’s Full Self-Driving (FSD) software now has 1.1 million active subscribers—up nearly 40% from a year earlier—and will become subscription-only after February 14. Tesla is expanding its robotaxi service to Dallas, Houston, Phoenix, Miami, Orlando, Tampa, and Las Vegas in the first half of 2026. The company launched automated rideshare operations in Austin in June 2025, began rolling out robotaxis without human supervisors in January 2026, and continues to operate non-autonomous rideshare services in the San Francisco Bay Area, with testing permits in Nevada and Arizona. The stock rose 1.2% in after-hours trading, reflecting investor optimism about Tesla’s AI and robotics future.

**Tesla Discontinues Model S and Model X, Paving the Way for Optimus Robot Production**
Tesla has announced the discontinuation of the Model S and Model X, marking the end of its flagship vehicle lineup as part of a strategic shift toward automation and the production of Optimus humanoid robots. The decision follows years of declining sales, with Model S and Model X combined accounting for a small percentage of Tesla's annual deliveries—over 1.7 million units annually since 2022—leading Tesla to stop reporting their sales separately starting in 2023, grouping them with Cybertruck and Tesla Semi under 'other vehicles.' The Fremont factory, which previously produced these models with a design capacity of about 100,000 units annually, has been operating at low capacity. Elon Musk cited 'autonomy' as the primary reason for the shutdown, stating that production lines will be repurposed for Optimus robots, with a target annual output of 1 million units. Tesla will continue providing after-sales service but will stop deliveries after the second quarter of 2026, with no further production once current inventory is depleted. A minor update in July 2025—adding new colors, a front camera, slightly improved range, and ambient lighting—was widely seen as a token gesture, with prices increased by $5,000 (Model S to $84,990, Model X to $89,990), signaling a farewell tour. Historically, Model S (2012–2026) and Model X (2015–2026) were pivotal in establishing Tesla’s brand, serving as financial foundations for the more mass-market Model 3 and Model Y, and defining the premium electric vehicle segment. However, platform aging and competition from Lucid Air and Rivian R1S have eroded their market leadership. Industry analysts, including Electrek, note that the decision was 'inevitable' from a manufacturing standpoint due to the high complexity and low volume of these models. The move symbolizes the end of an era, as these vehicles once inspired early adopters and forced traditional automakers to embrace electrification. With the discontinuation of Model S and Model X, Tesla has officially closed the chapter on its flagship era, redirecting resources toward future automation goals.

**Is Rivian Stock a Buy Now?**
Rivian Automotive (RIVN) is at a critical juncture in its development, with its long-term viability hinging on the success of its upcoming lower-priced truck, the R2, set for release in 2026. While Rivian has achieved notable milestones—producing award-winning vehicles, scaling production, and achieving gross profit in multiple quarters of 2024 and 2025—it remains unprofitable overall, with net losses persisting. The company posted a modest gross profit in Q4 2024, Q1 2025, and Q3 2025, but not in Q2 2025. Despite having $7 billion in cash as of Q3 2025, Rivian's future depends on its ability to transition from serving business customers and high-end consumers to capturing the mass market with the R2. The article cautions that while Rivian has made impressive progress, its capital-intensive nature and intense competition make mass-market success uncertain. The Motley Fool advises most investors to wait for evidence of the R2’s market reception before investing, noting that a weak launch could severely impact the company. The recommendation is to approach with caution and delay investment until post-launch performance data is available.

**Rivian's 2025 deliveries slip below expectations as EV demand pressure persists**
Rivian reported 42,247 electric vehicle deliveries in 2025, a decline of approximately 18% compared to the previous year, falling slightly below the 42,500 deliveries expected by analysts according to Visible Alpha data—representing a consensus forecast of a 17.6% drop. The company’s fourth-quarter 2025 delivery count was 9,745, below the Wall Street expectation of 10,050, while production reached 10,974 units at its Normal, Illinois plant. The decline underscores persistent pressure on demand for higher-priced EVs, exacerbated by the expiration of the US $7,500 federal tax credit at the end of September 2025, which led to higher vehicle prices. Rivian, which sells the R1T pickup and R1S SUV at premium price points, is under scrutiny over whether demand can remain resilient as it scales production. The company is implementing efficiency measures at its Illinois plant and simplifying vehicle components to reduce material and manufacturing costs in an effort to improve profitability without relying solely on volume growth. Investors are now focusing on the upcoming launch of the lower-cost R2 SUV, expected in the first half of 2026, which is positioned to compete with Tesla’s Model Y. Rivian plans to release its full-year and fourth-quarter 2025 financial results on February 12, after market close.

**Rivian follows Tesla in underperforming sales expectations**
Rivian Automotive reported 2025 delivery figures of 42,247 electric vehicles, an 18% decline from 2024 and slightly below analyst expectations of 42,500 units. The company delivered 9,745 vehicles in the fourth quarter, narrowly missing Wall Street's forecast of 10,050. Rivian produced 10,974 vehicles at its Normal, Illinois, facility during the same period. The decline follows the expiration of the $7,500 federal EV tax credit at the end of September 2025, which increased consumer prices and reduced demand. Premium models like the R1T and R1S were hit hardest due to economic volatility. Rivian is responding with efficiency measures at its Illinois plant and simplifying vehicle components to achieve sustainable profitability, as investor patience has waned since the 2020–2021 EV boom. The company is preparing to launch the R2 SUV in early 2026, targeting a lower price point to compete with Tesla’s Model Y and expand its customer base. Rivian’s CEO, RJ Scaringe, announced that point-to-point automated driving will debut in 2026, following the launch of Universal Hands-Free in December 2025 under the Rivian Autonomy+ subscription ($49.99/month or $2,500 one-time). The company will release full-year 2025 financial results on February 12, 2026. U.S. new EV sales in November 2025 totaled 70,255 units, a 41.2% drop year-on-year, with EV market share falling to 5.4%, the lowest since April 2022. Despite this, analysts project U.S. EV sales will reach 2.25 million by end-2025 and account for 11.8% of total sales in 2026. Tesla also underperformed in 2025, according to Cryptopolitan.

**Rivian Lost Thousands Of Buyers Almost Overnight | Carscoops**
Rivian reported a 31.3% decline in fourth-quarter 2025 vehicle deliveries, with 9,745 units delivered compared to 14,183 in the same period of 2024. For the full year 2025, deliveries totaled 42,247 vehicles, down from 51,579 in 2024, representing an 18.1% year-over-year decrease. Production also declined, with 10,974 units made in Q4 2025 (down from 12,727 in Q4 2024) and 42,284 for the year (down from 49,476). The company stated these declines were 'in line with their expectations,' attributing the drop to the elimination of the federal electric vehicle tax credit in September 2025. Rivian's stock fell 1.95% to $19.32 per share as of January 2, 2026, though it has risen significantly from $13.25 on January 2, 2025. Looking ahead, Rivian plans to launch the new R2 model in the first half of 2026, starting at $45,000, featuring an all-new platform, up to 300 miles (483 km) of range, and powertrains offering 0-60 mph (0-96 km/h) acceleration in under three seconds. The company also announced the rollout of Universal Hands-Free Driving on over 3.5 million miles (5,632,704 km) of roads in the U.S. and Canada, available via a new Autonomy+ subscription priced at $49.99/month or a one-time $2,500 fee. Rivian’s full-year 2025 financial results are scheduled for release on February 12, 2026.

**Rivian Stock: Why Bears Are Celebrating Despite Record Quarter**
Rivian reported record vehicle deliveries of 13,201 units in the third quarter of 2024, surpassing analyst estimates of 12,690 and marking a 32% increase from the previous quarter and a rise from 10,018 units in the same period of the prior year. Production at the Normal, Illinois plant reached 10,720 units. Despite the strong delivery numbers, Rivian's stock dropped by over 7%, driven by a revised annual guidance that now forecasts between 41,500 and 43,500 vehicles—down 500 units from the previous range of 40,000 to 46,000. The downward revision is attributed to the expiration of the $7,500 federal tax credit for electric vehicle leasing, which had previously supported demand. Experts predict a sharp decline in EV sales and leasing. Additionally, high import tariffs on auto parts are forcing Rivian to restructure supply chains and increase domestic production, raising costs. This cost pressure threatens Rivian’s efforts to improve profitability ahead of the 2025 launch of the more affordable R2 SUV. The company’s fourth-quarter financial results, expected on November 4, 2025, will reveal the extent of margin compression. The article concludes with a call for investors to assess whether to buy or sell based on the latest analysis from Aktien Check, published October 2, 2025.

**Cantor Fitzgerald Maintains Neutral Rating on Rivian, Forecasts Strong Q3**
Cantor Fitzgerald has kept its rating on Rivian Automotive Inc. at Neutral with a target price of $15.00, while the electric‑vehicle maker is approaching what analysts expect to be its strongest quarter of the year.  The stock, trading at $15.59, has risen 26% over the past six months, according to InvestingPro data.  The firm projects Rivian will deliver 15,675 vehicles in Q3 2025, surpassing the Visible Alpha Consensus estimate of 12,690 units.  Rivian’s management recently confirmed that Q3 would be the company’s best sales quarter during a lunch with investors in New York, where the CFO highlighted the company’s focus on the Rivian Autonomy Platform.  Production figures show 20,590 vehicles were built and 19,301 delivered in the first half of 2025, after a 2024 annual production of 41,476 units and 51,579 deliveries.  Rivian maintains its 2025 delivery forecast of 40,000–46,000 vehicles.  The next platform, R2, is slated to begin production in the first half of 2026, with a base price of roughly $45,000.  The company is also recalling more than 24,000 2025 R1S and R1T models due to a software defect in the Hands‑Free Highway Assist system, and its electric delivery vans are under investigation by the NHTSA for potential seat‑belt performance issues affecting about 17,198 vehicles.  Rivian has begun work on a new plant in Georgia that is expected to create 7,500 jobs by 2030 and will produce the next‑generation R2 SUV and R3 crossover, with construction starting in 2026 and production by 2028.  Amazon is testing GM BrightDrop electric vans alongside its existing Rivian fleet as part of a strategy to deploy 100,000 electric delivery vehicles by 2030.  "Il titolo, attualmente scambiato a 15,59 dollari, ha mostrato un forte slancio con un guadagno del 26% negli ultimi sei mesi," noted the analyst.  "La dirigenza di Rivian ha recentemente riaffermato che il Q3 sarebbe stato il suo trimestre più forte per le vendite di veicoli," added the CFO.

--- Deep Research Analysis ---
Based on available data through January 30, 2026:  
1. **Analyst Estimates for Q1 2026:**  
   No specific projections for Rivian's Q1 2026 deliveries appear in recent reports. Analysts are currently focused on Q4 2025 results (due February 12) and R2 production timelines [8][14][20].  

2. **Official Guidance Since January 2026:**  
   Rivian has not issued new delivery guidance for 2026 during January 2026. Its last annual forecast (2025) targeted 40,000–46,000 deliveries [1][11]. The company is expected to address 2026 outlook during its February 12 earnings call [20].  

**Supporting Context:**  
- Q4 2025 deliveries fell to 9,745 units (-31% YoY), attributed partly to the September 2025 expiration of EV tax credits [8][15][19].  
- The R2 SUV remains Rivian's key growth catalyst for 2026, with production starting in Normal, Illinois (not Georgia) by June 2026 [6][13].  
- Investor caution persists due to Rivian's 2025 delivery decline (-18% YoY) and unprofitability [11][14][19].
